pullrequest.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

content.raw:
thanks, I missed that one change to the docs

We can still get the old behavior by checking `IsValid() && IsPositive()` (with the minor caveat that the triangle inequality now uses `>=` instead of `>`).

As an aside, after reviewing the feature system code, this sounds like a policy
content.html:
thanks, I missed that one change to the docs

We can still get the old behavior by checking IsValid() && IsPositive() (with the minor caveat that the triangle inequality now uses >= instead of >).

As an aside, after reviewing the feature system code, this sounds like a policy

pull_request.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

update.description:
This PR updates a few validity checks in MassMatrix and Inertial to accept a tolerance value.

The use case is in [sdformat pr #429](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/429/expand-acceptable-massmatrix-moments-and/diff).
update.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

pull_request.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

pullrequest.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

pull_request.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

pullrequest.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

content.raw:
I noticed an inconsistency between the documented behavior and the actual behavior of `IsValid()`, so I changed the documentation here: [2ca7e20](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/2ca7e206740fd30a74b484a84be1a5ccce2156c1?at=default)

If `IsValid()` really *is* meant to check that the matrix is positive-definite, then we can change the documentation back and use `IsPositive(_tolerance)` instead of `IsNearPositive(_tolerance)` \(which is actually what I would prefer\). I’m approving the PR as-is, but I would approve it even more if we enforce positive-definiteness. But as I mention in my in-line comment, I understand that the positive-definiteness requirement may be a blocker for some users.
content.html:
I noticed an inconsistency between the documented behavior and the actual behavior of IsValid(), so I changed the documentation here: 2ca7e20

If IsValid() really is meant to check that the matrix is positive-definite, then we can change the documentation back and use IsPositive(_tolerance) instead of IsNearPositive(_tolerance) (which is actually what I would prefer). I’m approving the PR as-is, but I would approve it even more if we enforce positive-definiteness. But as I mention in my in-line comment, I understand that the positive-definiteness requirement may be a blocker for some users.

pull_request.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

pullrequest.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

content.raw:
It seems strange to me that a call to `IsValid(0)`with a tolerance that is explicitly `0` would return true on a positive semi-definite moment of inertia. I guess this goes back to the question of what “valid” really means, which is apparently hard to find a consensus for.

I'm fine with leaving it as-is if being more strict would be a blocker for people, but I have a feeling this might make people less willing to trust \(and therefore use\) the `ign-math` API.
content.html:
It seems strange to me that a call to IsValid(0)with a tolerance that is explicitly 0 would return true on a positive semi-definite moment of inertia. I guess this goes back to the question of what “valid” really means, which is apparently hard to find a consensus for.

I'm fine with leaving it as-is if being more strict would be a blocker for people, but I have a feeling this might make people less willing to trust (and therefore use) the ign-math API.

content.html: To avoid using a #define for a global constant, I changed IGN_MASSMATRIX3_DEFAULT_TOLERANCE into a variable template in this commit: 5956d8c

pull_request.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

pullrequest.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

content.raw: Previously this code considered Inertials and MassMatrices to be invalid if they were positive-semidefinite, but I hear there is a desire to allow some positive semi-definite inertia matrices to be considered valid. I would propose adding a function called `MassMatrix3::IsNearPositive` which uses `>=` so that `IsPositive` can continue using `>`. We can change `MassMatrix3::IsValid` to use `IsNearPositive`
content.html: Previously this code considered Inertials and MassMatrices to be invalid if they were positive-semidefinite, but I hear there is a desire to allow some positive semi-definite inertia matrices to be considered valid. I would propose adding a function called MassMatrix3::IsNearPositive which uses >= so that IsPositive can continue using >. We can change MassMatrix3::IsValid to use IsNearPositive

content.raw:
since we can now specify epsilon, I think this is more flexible, if we use `>` instead of `>=`

otherwise, this is no longer checking for positive definiteness; it's checking for positive semi-definiteness
content.html:
since we can now specify epsilon, I think this is more flexible, if we use > instead of >=

otherwise, this is no longer checking for positive definiteness; it's checking for positive semi-definiteness

pull_request.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

pullrequest.title: Update validity checks in MassMatrix to accept a tolerance

content.raw:
This test is just _slightly_ too strict -- the triangle inequality requires a+b>=c rather than just >. In practice the "=" condition is fairly common.
[Here ](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/blob/master/SimTKcommon/Mechanics/include/SimTKcommon/internal/MassProperties.h#L428) is the test we use in Simbody. I think we have something more sophisticated in Drake now -- Paul Mitiguy is the expert (mitiguy@tri.global).
content.html: This test is just slightly too strict -- the triangle inequality requires a+b>=c rather than just >. In practice the "=" condition is fairly common. Here is the test we use in Simbody. I think we have something more sophisticated in Drake now -- Paul Mitiguy is the expert (mitiguy@tri.global).

content.html: could you add a comment on why we expect this to be false? maybe worth documenting what the default constructor initializes the mass matrix to?

content.raw:
would you be able to document a bit more about how this tolerance is used? how/why a user would use this? just stating the math would be enough \(something similar to [the docs here](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/master/multibody/multibody_tree/rotational_inertia.h#L866) would be helpful\).

Something important for users of this method is, what are the units of `_tolerance`?
content.html:
would you be able to document a bit more about how this tolerance is used? how/why a user would use this? just stating the math would be enough (something similar to the docs here would be helpful).

Something important for users of this method is, what are the units of _tolerance?
